abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second
            Bhairawa-Lumbini Groundwater Project for Nepal was
            successful. The project achieved all physical works
            envisaged at appraisal, its impact on agricultural
            development has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and both the Bank and Borrower performed satisfactorily.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            when water from a tubewell is shared by 100 different
            farmers, imposing a disciplined O&M (Operation &
            Maintenance) system is crucial to project success. Second,
            the DCA (Development Credit Agreement) was amended to allow
            for the submission of accounts and audit reports up to 12
            months after the closing date of the fiscal year. Third,
            unnecessary stipulations in the DCA that failure by farmers
            to carry out the construction of field channels will cause
            the project to undertake this construction and recover the
            costs from the beneficiaries. Fourth, as lowland areas
            minimize the use of irrigation water, the selection of areas
            for construction of tubewell irrigation systems should be
            carefully done. Lastly, the use of SA (Special Accounts)
            should be avoided in the future if HMGN's (His
            Majesty's Government of Nepal) rules cannot be simplified.
